step_by_step_thinking: The patient is an African-American woman with a family history of melanoma. MEDCORP documents state that acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is disproportionately higher in non-white populations, including African-Americans, compared to other melanoma subtypes. ALM accounts for 33-36% of CMM in Blacks and has higher incidence in non-white patients. Family history of melanoma increases risk, and ALM is more common in darker-skinned individuals. Other subtypes like superficial spreading are more prevalent in lighter-skinned populations. The answer is C.
